inscription.text: Roma
Rome

Gab. Palaeotio Pontifico Stlitib Iudicandis Duodecimviro integerrimo. Expressi iandudum mi Reuer. Dne meis aeneis tabellis Io. Antonii Dosii floren. manu delineatis Urbem Romam Urbium, ac Terraru, gentiumque, omnium, Reginam qualis qualis his temporibus apparet, et, ut ea in lucem prodiret audentius, tuo nomini dicata exit, quod huiusce Urbis te amantissimum fuisse semper accepi: proinde editam tibi, do, dicoq, ac trado. Vale Barptolaemei Phaletii tui nominis semp obseruantissimi memor. Romae Calendis Ianuarii MDLXI. Sebastianus a Regibus Clodiensis in aere incidebat.

Gabrielo Palaeotio Pontifico Stlitibus Iudicandis Duodecimviro integerrimo. Expressi iandudum mi Reuerende Domine meis aeneis tabellis Iohannis Antonii Dosii florentini manu delineatis Urbem Romam Urbium, ac Terrarum, gentiumque omnium, Reginam qualis qualis his temporibus apparet, et, ut ea in lucem prodiret audentius, tuo nomini dicata exit, quod huiusce Urbis te amantissimum fuisse semper accepi: proinde editam tibi, do, dicoque, ac trado. Vale Barptolaemei Phaletii tui nominis semper obseruantissimi memor. Romae Calendis Ianuarii MDLXI. Sebastianus a Regibus Clodiensis in aere incidebat.

Gab(rielo) Palaeotio Pontifico Stlitib(us) Iudicandis Duodecimviro Integerrimo. Expressi iandudum mi Reuer(ende) D(omi)ne meis aeneis tabellis Io(hannis) Antonii Dosii floren(tini) manu delineatis Urbem Romam Urbium, ac Terraru(m), gentiumq(ue) omnium, Reginam qualis qualis his temporibus apparet, et, ut ea in lucem prodiret audentius, tuo nomini dicata exit, quod huiusce Urbis te amantissimum fuisse semper accepi: proinde editam tibi, do, dicoq(ue), ac trado. Vale Barptolaemei Phaletii tui nominis semp(er) obseruantissimi memor. Romae Calendis Ianuarii MDLXI. Sebastianus a Regibus Clodiensis in aere incidebat.

My reverend master, I printed this without delay from my bronze plates designed by the hand of the Florentine Giovanni Antonio Dosio the city Rome, Queen of all cities and all lands and all peoples, such as it appears at this time so that she comes forth into the light more fully. It is published dedicated to your name because I take you to have always been most fond of this city, and accordingly I give, I devote, and I deliver to you this publication. Be well, remembering Bartolomeo Faleti always most attentive to your name. At Rome, on the First of January 1561. Sebastiano Re de Chioggia engraved it in bronze.
Sebastianus a Regibus Clodiensis in aere incidebat.
Sebastiano Re de Chioggia engraved it in bronze.

inscription.text: Pantheum Romanum nunc Mariae cognomento rotundae notum ad antiquam suam effigiem formam expressum.
Pantheum Romanum nunc Mariae cognomento rotundae notum ad antiquam suam effigiem et formam expressum.
The Roman Pantheon, now called Mary Rotunda, known for its ancient shape and distinct form.
M. Agrippa L. f. cos. tertum fecit.
Marcus Agrippa Lucii filius consul tertum fecit.
M(arcus) Agrippa L(ucii) f(ilius) co(n)s(ul) tertium fecit.

M(arcus) Agrippa, L(uci) f(ilius), co(n)s(ul) tertium fecit.
{CIL VI.896 cf. VI 31196 cf. VI p. 3777 et VI p. 4303}
Marcus Agrippa, son of Lucius, consul for the third time, constructed this.

Imp. Caes. L. Septimius Severus Pius Pertinax Arabicus Adiabenicus Parthicus pont. max. trib. pot. XI cos. III p. p. procos. et Imp. Caes. M. Aurelius Antoninus Pius Felix Aug. trib. potest. V cos. procos. Pantheum vetustate corruptum cum omni cultu restituerunt.

Imperator Caesar Lucius Septimius Severus Pius Pertinax Arabicus Adiabenicus Parthicus pontifex maximus tribunicia potestate XI consul III pater patriae proconsul et Imperator Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Pius Felix Augustus tribunicia potestate V consul proconsul Pantheum vetustate corruptum cum omni cultu restituerunt.

Imp(erator) Caes(ar) L(ucius) Septimius Severus Pius Pertinax Arabicus Adiabenicus Parthicus pont(ifex) max(imus) trib(unicia) pot(estate) XI co(n)s(ul) III p(ater) p(atriae) proco(n)s(ul) et | Imp(erator) Caes(ar) M(arcus) Aurelius Antoninus Pius Felix Aug(ustus) trib(unicia) potest(ate) V co(n)s(ul) proco(n)s(ul) Pantheum vetustate corruptum cum omni cultu restituerunt.
NOTE: There are several places in which this inscription as given in the print differs from the original inscription on the Pantheon. In the first line of this inscription, the name of the emperor is given as “L(ucius) Septimius Severus Pius Pertinax…”. In the actual inscription on the Pantheon, the name “Severus” does not appear. In the same line, “Aug(ustus)” is missing after “Pertinax” and “Parthicus” should be “Parthicus Maximus”. Also in line one, “pont(ifex) max(imus) trib(unicia) pot(estate) XI” should be “pontif(ex) max(imus) trib(unicia) potest(ate) X”. In the second line, “trib(unicia) potest(ate) V” should be “trib(unicia) potestat(e) V”. Compare with Source Text below.

Emperor Caesar Lucius Septimius Severus Pius Pertinax Arabicus Adiabenicus Parthicus, Pontifex Maximus, invested with the tribunician power eleven times, consul three times, father of the fatherland, proconsul and Emperor Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Pius Felix Augustus, invested with the tribunician power five times, consul, proconsul restored the Pantheon, ruined by age, with greatest care.

Labrum ex porphyrite, et duos ex ophite Leones Aegyptiis notis illistres, ex prosximis ut opinor Agrippae ac Neronis thermis, in celebriorem et ampliorem locum, pii Pontifices Maximi, ne situ squalloreve iacerent, propter Pantheum erigi collocarique iusserunt.

Labrum ex porphyrite, et duos ex ophite Leones Aegyptiis notis illistres, ex prosximis ut opinor Agrippae ac Neronis thermis, in celebriorem et ampliorem locum, pii Pontifices Maximi, ne situ squalloreve iacerent, propter Pantheum erigi collocarique iusserunt.

Lest they remain lying in a deserted place, the pius popes ordered that this basin made of porphyry and these two Egyptian lions of serpentino marble, famous and illustrious, which are, as I judge, from the nearby baths of Agrippa and Nero, be removed and erected near the Pantheon.
Ant. Lafreri Romae 1549
Antonius Lafreri Romae 1549
Ant(onius) Lafreri Romae 1549
Antonio Lafreri (published it) in Rome, 1549

The Roman Pantheon, now called Mary Rotunda, known for its ancient shape and distinct form.
M. AGRIPPA. L. F. COS. TERTIUM FECIT.
MARCUS AGRIPPA LUCII FILIUS CONSUL TERTIUM FECIT.
M(arcus) Agrippa L(ucii) f(ilius) co(n)s(ul) tertium fecit.

M(arcus) Agrippa, L(uci) f(ilius), co(n)s(ul) tertium fecit.
{CIL VI.896 cf. VI 31196 cf. VI p. 3777 et VI p. 4303}

IMP. CAES. L. SEPTIMIUS SEVERUS PIUS PERTINAX ARABICUS ADIABENICUS PARTHICUS PONT. MAX. TRIB. POT. XI COS. III P. P. PROCOS. ET IMP. CAES. M. AURELIUS ANTONINUS PIUS FELIX AUG. TRIB. POTEST. V COS. PROCOS. PANTHEUM VETUSTATE CORUPTUM CUM OMNI CULTU RESTITUERUNT.

IMPERATOR CAESAR LUCIUS SEPTIMIUS SEVERUS PIUS PERTINAX ARABICUS ADIABENICUS PARTHICUS PONTIFEX MAXIMUS TRIBUNICIA POTESTATE XI CONSUL III PATER PATRIAE PROCONSUL ET IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCUS AURELIUS ANTONINUS PIUS FELIX AUGUSTUS TRIBUNICIA POTESTATE V CONSUL PROCONSUL PANTHEUM VETUSTATE CORUPTUM CUM OMNI CULTU RESTITUERUNT.

Imp(erator) Caes(ar) L(ucius) Septimius Severus Pius Pertinax Arabicus Adiabenicus Parthicus pont(ifex) max(imus) trib(unicia) pot(estate) XI co(n)s(ul) III p(ater) p(atriae) proco(n)s(ul) et | Imp(erator) Caes(ar) M(arcus) Aurelius Antoninus Pius Felix Aug(ustus) trib(unicia) potest(ate) V co(n)s(ul) proco(n)s(ul) Pantheum vetustate coruptum cum omni cultu restituerunt.
NOTE: There are several places in which this inscription as given in the print differs from the original inscription on the Pantheon. In the first line of this inscription, the name of the emperor is given as “L(ucius) Septimius Severus Pius Pertinax…”. In the actual inscription on the Pantheon, the name “Severus” does not appear. In the same line, “Aug(ustus)” is missing after “Pertinax,” and “Parthicus” should be “Parthicus Maximus.” Also in line one, “pont(ifex) max(imus) trib(unicia) pot(estate) XI” should be “pontif(ex) max(imus) trib(unicia) potest(ate) X”. In the second line, “trib(unicia) potest(ate) V” should be “trib(unicia) potestat(e) V”, and “coruptum” should be “corruptum”. Compare with Source Text below.

Emperor Caesar Lucius Septimius Severus Pius Pertinax Arabicus Adiabenicus Parthicus, Pontifex Maximus, Invested with the Tribunician Power for the 11th time, Consul three times, Father of the Fatherland, Proconsul and Emperor Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Pius Felix Augustus invested with the Tribunician Power for the fifth time, Consul, Proconsul restored the Pantheon, ruined by age, with greatest care.

descriptionSet.description: The Arch of Titus is shown here reconstructed and free from encumbering constructions. In the medieval period it was built into the fortress of the Frangipani family. The arch was freed from later constructions and restored in 1822. For further information see Richardson, pg. 30, s.v. Arcus Titi (2).

inscription.text: Imp Caes Lucio Septimio M fil Severo Pio Pertinaci Aug patri patriae Parthico Arabico et Parthico Adiabenico pontif maximo tribunic potest XI Imp XI cos III procos et imp Caes M Aurelio L Fil Antonino Aug Pio Felici tribunic potest VI cos procos p p optimis fortissimisque principibus ob rem publicam restitutam imperiumque populi romani propagatum insignibus virtutibus eorum domi forisque SPQR

Imperatori Caesari Lucio Septimio Marci filio Severo Pio Pertinaci Augusto patri patriae Parthico Arabico et Parthico Adiabenico pontifici maximo tribunicia potestate XI Imperatori XI consuli III proconsuli et Imperatori Caesari Marco Aurelio Lucii filio Antonino Augusto Pio Felici tribunicia potestate VI consuli proconsuli patri patriae optimis fortissimisque principibus ob rem publicam restitutam imperiumque populi romani propagatum insignibus virtutibus eorum domi forisque Senatus Populusque Romanus

Imp(eratori) Caes(ari) Lucio Septimio M(arci) fil(io) Severo Pio Pertinaci Aug(usto), patri patriae, Parthico Arabico et | Parthico Adiabenico, pontif(ici) max(imo), tribunic(ia) potest(ate) XI, imp(eratori) XI, co(n)s(uli) III, proco(n)s(uli), et | Imp(eratori) Caes(ari) M(arco) Aurelio L(ucii) f(ilio) Antonino Aug(usto) Pio Felici, tribunic(ia) potest(ate) VI, co(n)s(uli), proco(n)s(uli), p(atri) p(atriae), | optimis fortissimisque principibus, | ob rem publicam restitutam imperiumque populi romani propagatum | insignibus virtutibus eorum domi forisque, S(enatus) P(opulus)Q(ue) R(omanus)
NOTE: On the actual arch, the word "Pontifici" is abbreviated to "Pontific" rather than "Pontif" as appears in this print. The decision to leave out additional letters was likely due to spatial constraints. See Source Text below.

Ìmp(eratori) Caes(ari) Lucio Septimio M(arci) fil(io) Severo Pio Pertinaci Aug(usto) patri patriae Parthico Arabico et
Parthico Adiabenico, pontific(i) maximo, tribunic(ia) potest(ate) X̅I̅, ìmp(eratori) X̅I̅, co(n)s(uli) I̅I̅I̅, proco(n)s(uli) et
Ìmp(eratori) Caes(ari) M(arco) Aurelio L(uci) fil(io) Antonino Aug(usto) Pio Felici, tribunic(ia) potest(ate) V̅I̅, co(n)s(uli), proco(n)s(uli), 《p(atri) p(atriae)》,
《optimis fortissimisque principibus》
5 ob rem publicam restitutam imperiumque populi Romani propagatum
insignibus virtutibus eorum domi forisque s(enatus) p(opulus)q(ue) R(omanus).
{CIL VI.1033 cf. VI 31230 et VI 36881 et VI p. 4318 et VI p. 4351 (ad 36881)}

To the Emperor Caesar Lucius Septimius Severus, son of Marcus, Pius, Pertinax, Augustus, Pater Patriae, Parthicus Arabicus and Parthicus Adiabenicus, Pontifex Maximus, granted the Tribunician power for the eleventh time, acclaimed victorius general for the eleventh time, consul for the third time, proconsul; and to the Emperor Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, son of Lucius, Augustus, Pius, Felix, granted the Tribunician power for the sixth time, consul, proconsul, Pater Patriae; to both men, the best and bravest emperors, for having saved the Republic and expanded the dominion of the Roman people and for their remarkable virtue, at home and abroad, the Senate and the People of Rome (dedicate this arch).
Ant. Lafr. sequanus exc.
Antonius Lafreri Sequanus excudit.
Ant(onius) Lafr(erius) Sequanus exc(udit).
Antonio Lafreri the Frenchman published it.

To the Emperor Caesar Lucius Septimius Severus, son of Marcus, Pius, Pertinax, Augustus, Pater Patriae (Father of the Fatherland), Parthicus, Adiabenicus, Pontifex Maximus, granted the Tribunician power for the eleventh time, acclaimed victorius general for the eleventh time, consul for the third time, proconsul; and to the Emperor Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, son of Lucius, Augustus, Pius, Felix, granted the Tribunician power for the sixth time, consul, proconsul, Pater Patriae; to both men, the best and bravest emperors, for having saved the Republic and expanded the dominion of the Roman people and for their remarkable virtue, at home and abroad, the Senate and the People of Rome (dedicate this arch).

inscription.text: IMP. CAES. FL. CONSTANTINO MAXIMO P. F. AUGUSTO S.P.Q.R. QUOD INSTINCTU DIVINITATIS MENTIS MAGNITUDINE CUM EXERCITU SUO TAMDE TIRANNO QUAM DE OMNI EIUS FACTIONE UNO TEMPORE IUSTIS REM PUBLICAM ULTUS EST ARMIS ARCUM TRIUMPHIS INSIGNEM DICAVIT.

IMPERATORI CAESARI FLAVIO CONSTANTINO MAXIMO PIO FELICI AUGUSTO SENATUS POPULUSQUE ROMANO QUOD INSTINCTU DIVINITATIS MENTIS MAGNITUDINE CUM EXERCITU SUO TAM DE TIRANNO QUAM DE OMNI EIUS FACTIONE UNO TEMPORE IUSTIS REMPUBLICAM ULTUS EST ARMIS ARCUM TRIUMPHIS INSIGNEM DICAVIT.

Imp(eratori) Caes(ari) Fl(avio) Constantino Maximo | P(io) F(elici) Augusto S(enatus) P(opulus)q(ue) R(omanus) | quod instinctu divinitatis mentis | magnitudine cum exercitu suo | tam de tiranno quam de omni eius | factione uno tempore iustis | rem publicam ultus est armis | arcum triumphis insignem dicavit.
NOTE: In the 5th line of the inscription on the arch in this print, “tiranno” should be spelled “tyranno.” See Source Text below.

〈:in utraque facie〉
Imp(eratori) Caes(ari) Fl(avio) Constantino Maximo
P(io) F(elici) Augusto, S(enatus) P(opulus)q(ue) R(omanus),
quod instinctu divinitatis, mentis
magnitudine, cum exercitu suo
tam de tyranno quam de omni eius
factione, uno tempore, iustis
rem publicam ultus est armis,
arcum triumphis insignem dicavit.
〈:in latere ad septentrionem verso〉
votis X votis XX.
〈:in latere ad meridionem verso〉
sic X sic XX.
〈:intra fornicem, ab una parte〉
liberatori urbis.
〈:intra fornicem, ab altera parte〉
fundatori quietis.
{CIL VI.1139 cf. VI 31245 et VI p. 3778 et VI p. 4328}

To the Emperor Caesar Flavius Constantinus Maximus Pius Felix Augustus, the Senate and the People of Rome dedicate this arch as a memorial to his military triumphs, who by the inspiration of divinity and his own genius avenged, with righteous arms in one instant, the Republic against the tyrant and his faction.
Romae Claudii ducheti Formis 1583
At the press of Claudio Duchetti in Rome, 1583.

inscription.text: Amphitheatri Veronen. diligens et accurata delineatio, quod ludis publicis, gladiatorio muneri, et ferarum venationib. exhibendis, Imp. Caes. Aug. suasu, post bella civil. pace Pop. Ro. terra mariq parta nobilissima colonia Verona, opere rustico, in foro boario extra Urb. moenia, aere publico collocavit. Unum omnium quae nobis antiquitas reliquit, Civium perpetua diligentia, et quantum humana ope praestari potuit, magis a temporum iniuria praeseruatum. Anteriorem enim porticuum partem, quam alam vocant, ingenti terremotu quassatam, anno salut mcxvii corruisse annalibus Veronensium proditum est.

Amphitheatri Veronensis diligens et accurata delineatio, quod ludis publicis, gladiatorio muneri, et ferarum venationibus exhibendis, Imperatore Caesare Augugusto suasu, post bella civilia pace Populi Romani terra marique parta nobilissima colonia Verona, opere rustico, in foro boario extra Urbis moenia, aere publico collocavit. Unum omnium quae nobis antiquitas reliquit, Civium perpetua diligentia, et quantum humana ope praestari potuit, magis a temporum iniuria praeseruatum. Anteriorem enim porticuum partem, quam alam vocant, ingenti terremotu quassatam, anno salutis mcxvii corruisse annalibus Veronensium proditum est.

Amphitheatri Veronen(sis) diligens et accurata delineatio, quod ludis publicis, gladiatorio muneri, et ferarum venationib(us) exhibendis, Imp(eratore) Caes(are) Aug(ugusto) suasu, post bella civil(ia) pace Pop(uli) Ro(mani) terra mariq(ue) parta nobilissima colonia Verona, opere rustico, in foro boario extra Urb(is) moenia, aere publico collocavit. Unum omnium quae nobis antiquitas reliquit, Civium perpetua diligentia, et quantum humana ope praestari potuit, magis a temporum iniuria praeseruatum. Anteriorem enim porticuum partem, quam alam vocant, ingenti terremotu quassatam, anno salut(is) mcxvii corruisse annalibus Veronensium proditum est.

A most accurate and careful sketch of the Amphitheatre of Verona…With peace having been brought forth on land and sea for the Roman People after the Civil Wars, the most noble colony Verona, on the advice of the Emperor Caesar Augustus, arranged for the exhibition of public games, gladiatorial offerings, and wild beast hunts with public money in the cattle-market outside the walls of the city for rural need. One of all the monuments which antiquity has handed down to us by the perpetual diligence of citizens and which could be preserved by human effort greatly protected from the injuries of time. It was even recorded in the annals of Verona that the previous side of the colonnade called the wing, shaken by a huge earthquake, had collapsed.
Romae Anno MDLX. Anton(ii) Lafrerii Sequani formis ad genitivum archetypum fidelissime expressa.

inscription.text: IMP. CAESAR DIVI IULI F. AUGUSTUS PONTIFEX MAXIMUS COS. XII TRIBUNIC. POTESTAT. XIX IMP. XIIII RIVOS AQUARUM OMNIUM REFECIT
IMPERATOR CAESAR DIVI IULI FILIUS AUGUSTUS PONTIFEX MAXIMUS CONSUL XII TRIBUNICIA POTESTATE XIX IMPERATOR XIIII RIVOS AQUARUM OMNIUM REFECIT.
Imp(erator) Caesar divi Iuli f(ilius) Augustus | pontifex maximus co(n)s(ul) XII, | tribunic(ia) potestat(e) XIX, imp(erator) XIIII, | rivos aquarum omnium refecit.

Imp(erator) Caesar Divi Iuli f(ilius) Augustus,
pontifex maximus, co(n)s(ul) XII,
tribunic(ia) potestat(e) XIX, imp(erator) XIIII,
rivos aquarum omnium refecit.
{CIL VI 1244 cf. VI p. 3125 et VI p. 3797 et VI p. 4363}

Emperor Caesar Augustus, son of the divine Julius, pontifex maximus, consul for the 12th time, holder of the tribunican power for the 19th year, hailed imperator 14 times, restored the courses of all the aqueducts.

IMP. CAES. M. AURELIUS ANTONINUS PIUS FELIX AUG. PARTH. MAXIM. BRIT. MAXIMUS PONTIFEX MAXIMUS AQUAM MARCIAM VARIIS KASIBUS IMPEDITAM PURGATO FONTE EXCISIS ET PERFORATIS MONTIBUS RESTITUTA FORMA ADQUISITO ETIAM FONTE NOVO ANTONIANO IN SACRAM URBEM SUAM PERDUCENDAM CURAVIT.

IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCUS AURELIUS ANTONINUS PIUS FELIX AUGUSTUS PARTHICUS MAXIMUS BRITANNICUS MAXIMUS PONTIFEX MAXIMUS AQUAM MARCIAM VARIIS KASIBUS IMPEDITAM PURGATO FONTE EXCISIS ET PERFORATIS MONTIBUS RESTITUTA FORMA ADQUISITO ETIAM FONTE NOVO ANTONIANO IN SACRAM URBEM SUAM PERDUCENDAM CURAVIT.

Imp(erator) Caes(ar) M(arcus) Aurelius Antoninus Pius Felix Aug(ustus) Parth(icus) Maxim(us), | Brit(annicus) Maximus, pontifex maximus | aquam Marciam variis kasibus impeditam purgato fonte excisis et perforatis | montibus restituta forma adquisito etiam fonte novo Antoniniano | in sacrem urbem suam perducendam curavit.

Imp(erator) Caes(ar) M(arcus) Aurellius Antoninus Pius Felix Aug(ustus), Parth(icus) maxim(us),
Brit(annicus) maximus, pontifex maximus,
aquam Marciam variis kasibus impeditam, purgato fonte, excisis et perforatis
montibus, restituta forma, adquisito etiam fonte novo Antoniniano,
in sacram Urbem suam perducendam curavit.
{CIL VI 1245 cf. VI p. 3125 et VI p. 3797 et VI p. 4363 et IX 606*, 1}

Emperor Marcus Aurelius Antonius Pius Felix Augustus, Parthicus Maximus, Britannicus Maximus, pontifex maximus, restored at his own expense the aqua Marcia, impeded by various accidents, its form restored by cleansing the spring and razing and piercing mountains as well as by adding a new Antoninian source, he took care that the aqueduct was restored to the holy city.

IMP. TITUS CAESAR DIVI F. VESPASIANUS AUG. PONTIF. MAX. TRIBUNICIAE POTESTAT. IX IMP. XV CENS. COS. VII DESIG. IIX RIVOM AQUAE MARCIAE VETUSTATE DILAPSUM REFECIT ET AQUAM QUAE IN USU ESSE DESIERAT REDUXIT.

IMPERATOR TITUS CAESAR DIVI FILIUS VESPASIANUS AUGUSTUS PONTIFEX MAXIMUS TRIBUNICIAE POTESTATIS IX IMPERATOR XV CENSOR CONSUL VII DESIGNATUS IIX RIVOM AQUAE MARCIAE VETUSTATE DILAPSUM REFECIT ET AQUAM QUAE IN USU ESSE DESIERAT REDUXIT.

Imp(erator) Titus Caesar divi f(ilius) Vespasianus Aug(ustus), pontif(ex) max(imus) | tribuniciae potestat(is) IX, imp(erator) XV, cens(or), co(n)s(ul) VII, desig(natus) IIX, | rivom aquae Marciae vetustate dilapsum refecit | et aquam quae in usu esse desierat reduxit.
NOTE: In the first line of this inscription, “Caesar” is engraved in full although on the actual monument it is abbreviated to “Caes.” Also in the first line, the word “maximus” is abbreviated in the print to “max” while on the monument it is abbreviated to “maxim.” At the end of the second line, “P P” for “pater patriae” is missing on the print. Compare with Source Text below.

Imp(erator) Titus Caes(ar) Divi F(ilius) Vespasianus Aug(ustus),
pontif(ex) maxim(us), tribuniciae potestat(is), I̅X̅ Imp(erator),
X̅V̅ cens(or), co(n)s(ul) V̅I̅I̅ desig(natus) I̅I̅X̅, p(ater) p(atriae),
rivom aquae Marciae vetustate dilapsum refecit,
et aquam quae in u`su´ esse desierat reduxit.
{CIL VI 1246 cf. VI p. 3125 et VI p. 3797 et VI p. 4363}

Emperor Titus Caesar Vespanian Augustus, son of the divine (Vespasian), pontifus maximus, holder of the tribunican power for the 9th time, hailed imperator 15 times, censor, consul for the 7th time, consul-elect for the 8th time, rebuilt the stream of the aqua Marcia, decayed by old age, and restored the water which had ceased to be in use.
Aquarum Marciae, Tepulae, et Juliae forma, quae nunc S. Laurentii porta vulgo appellatur. Ant. Lafreri typis Romae Anno sal. MDLXVI.
Aquarum Marciae, Tepulae, et Juliae forma, quae nunc Sancti Laurentii porta vulgo appellatur. Antonii Lafreri typis Romae Anno salutis MDLXVI.
Aquarum Marciae, Tepulae, et Juliae forma, quae nunc S(ancti) Laurentii porta vulgo appellatur. Ant(onii) Lafreri typis Romae Anno sal(utis) MDLXVI.
The Appearance of the waters of Marica, Tepula, and Julia, now popularly called the gate of Saint Lawrence. From the printing house of Antonio Lafreri at Rome, in the year of salvation 1566.
Ant. Lafreri typis Romae Anno sal. MDLXVI.
Antonii Lafreri typis Romae Anno salutis MDLXVI.
Ant(onii) Lafreri typis Romae Anno sal(utlis) MDLXVI.
From the printing house of Antonio Lafreri at Rome, in the year of salvation 1566.

inscription.text: Veteris aquae Claudiae ex Tiburtino forma; via portaque Naevia ac Labicana, nunc Maioris appellatione, notissima; servatis architecturae legibus, et eadem in anteriore exterioreque parte, uncialium litterarum inscriptione repetita; nobilis.

Veteris aquae Claudiae ex Tiburtino forma; via portaque Naevia ac Labicana, nunc Maioris appellatione, notissima; servatis architecturae legibus, et eadem in anteriore exterioreque parte, uncialium litterarum inscriptione repetita; nobilis.

Appearance of the ancient Aqua Claudia built from Travertine; The famous street and gate called Naevia or Labicana, today called the "Porta Maggiore"; preserved by the condition of the architecture, with inscription in uncial letters repeated on both the interior and exterior side; renowned.

Ti Claudius Drusi f Caesar Augustus Germanicus pontif. maxim. tribunicia potestate XII cos V imperator XXVII pater patriae aquas claudiam ex fontibus qui vocabantur Caeruleus et Curtius a milliario XXXXV item Anienem Novam a milliario LXII sua impensa in urbem perducendas curavit

Tiberius Claudius Drusi filius Caesar Augustus Germanicus Pontifex maximus tribunicia potestate XII consul V imperatoR XXVII pater patriae Aquas Claudiam ex fontibus qui vocabantur Caeruleus et Curtius a milliario XXXXV item Anienem Novam a milliario LXII sua impensa in urbem perducendas curavit.

Ti(berius) Claudius Drusi f(ilius) Caesar Augustus Germanicus pontif(ex) maxim(us) | tribunicia potestate XII co(n)s(ul) V imperator XXVII pater patriae | Aquas Claudiam ex fontibus qui vocabantur Caeruleus et Curtius a milliario XXXXV | item anienem novam a milliario LXII sua impensa in urbem perducendas curavit.
NOTE: In the first line of this inscription on the Porta Maggiore "Caesar" is actually spelled "Caisar". See Source Text below.

Tiberius Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus, son of Drusus, pontifex maximus, invested with the tribunican power twelve times, consul for the 5th time, hailed imperator 27 times, father of the fatherland, provided for at his own expense that the Claudian Aqueduct be brought from the 45th milestone, from the springs which are called the Caeruleus and the Curtius, and also that the Anio Novus be brought from the 62nd milestone into the city of Rome.

〈:in utroque latere〉
Ti(berius) Claudius Drusi f(ilius) Caisar Augustus Germanicus, pontif(ex) maxim(us),
tribunicia potestate X̅I̅I̅, co(n)s(ul) V̅, imperator X̅X̅V̅I̅I̅, pater patriae,
aquas Claudiam ex fontibus, qui vocabantur Caeruleus et Curtius, a milliario XXXXV,
item Anienem Novam, a milliario LXII, sua impensa, in urbem perducendas curavit.
{CIL VI 1256 cf. VI p. 3129 et VI p. 3798 et VI p. 4365}

Imp. Caesar Vespasianus August. pontif. max. trib. pot. II imp. VI cos. III desig. IIII p.p. Aquas Curtiam et caeruleam perductas a Divo Claudio et postea intermissas dilapsas que per annos novem sua impensa urbi restituit.

Imperator Caesar Vespasianus Augustustus pontifex maximus tribunicia potestate II imperator VI consul III designatus IIII pater patriae Aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perductas a Divo Claudio et postea intermissas dilapsas que per annos novem sua impensa urbi restituit.

Imp(erator) Caesar Vespasianus August(us) pontif(ex) max(imus) trib(unicia) pot(estate) II imp(erator) VI co(n)s(ul) III desig(natus) IIII p(ater) p(atriae) | aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perductas a Divo Claudio et postea intermissas dilapsasque | per annos novem sua impensa urbi restituit.

The Emperor Caesar Vespasian Augustus, pontifex maximus, invested with the tribunican power two times, hailed imperator six times, consul-elect for the 4th time, father of the fatherland, restored at his own expense for the city of Rome the aqueducts led from the Curtius and Caerulus by the divine Claudius and since interrupted and ruined for nine years.

〈:in utroque latere〉
Imp(erator) Caesar Vespasianus August(us), pontif(ex) max(imus), trib(unicia) pot(estate) I̅I̅, imp(erator) V̅I̅, co(n)s(ul) I̅I̅I̅, desig(natus) I̅I̅I̅I̅, p(ater) p(atriae),
aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perductas a divo Claudio et postea intermissas dìlapsasque
per annos novem sua impensa urbi restituit.
{CIL VI 1257 cf. VI p. 3129 et VI p. 3798 et VI p. 4365}

Imp. T. Caesar Divi f. Vespasianus Augustus pontifex maximus tribunic. potestate X imperator XVII pater patriae censor cos. VIII Aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perducatas a Divo Claudio et postea a Divo Vespasiano patre suo urbi restitutas cum a capite aquarum a solo vetustate dilapsae essent nova forma reducendas sua impensa curavit.

Imperator Titus Caesar divi filius Vespasianus Augustus pontifex maximus tribunicia potestate X imperator XVII pater patriae censor consul VIII Aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perducatas a Divo Claudio et postea a Divo Vespasiano patre suo urbi restitutas cum a capite aquarum a solo vetustate dilapsae essent nova forma reducendas sua impensa curavit.

Imp(erator) T(itus) Caesar divi f(ilius) Vespasianus Augustus pontifex maximus tribunic(ia) | potestate X imperator XVII pater patriae censor co(n)s(ul) VIII | aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perductas a divo Claudio et postea | a Divo Vespasiano patre suo urbi restitutas cum a capite aquarum a solo vetustate dilapsae essent nova forma reducendas sua impensa curavit.

Emperor Titus Claudius Caesar Vespasian Augustus, son of the divine Vespasian, pontifex maximus, invested with the tribunican power ten times, hailed imperator seventeen times, father of the fatherland, censor, consul for the 8th time, at his own expense provided that the Curtian and Caerulean waters that had been brought forth by the divine Claudius and afterwards had been restored for the city of Rome by his father the divine Vespasian, since they had falled into disrepair at the source of the waters from the very foundation because of age, be brought back again but in a new channel.

〈:in utroque latere〉
Imp(erator) T(itus) Caesar dìvì f(ilius) Vespasianus Augustus, pontifex maximus, tribunic(ia)
potestate X̅, imperator X̅V̅I̅I̅, pater patriae, censor, co(n)sul V̅I̅II̅
aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perductas a dìvo Claudio et postea
a dìvo Vespasiano, patre suo, urbi restitutas, cum a capite aquarum a solo vetustate dìlapsae essent, nova forma reducendas sua impensa curavit.
{CIL VI 1258 cf. VI p. 3129 et VI p. 3798 et VI p. 4365}
Antonii Lafrerii Romae 1549
[Published by] Antonio Lafreri at Rome 1549

inscription.text: S.P.Q.R. IMP. CAESARI DIVI NERVAE F. NERVA TRAIANO AUG. GERMANIC. DACICO PONT. MAX. TRIB. POT. XVII COS. VI P. P. AD DECLARANDU[M] QUANTAE ALTITUDINIS MONS ET LOCUS SIT EGESTUS.

SENATUS POPULUSQUE ROMANUS IMPERATORI CAESARI DIVI NERVAE FILIO NERVAE TRAIANO AUGUSTO GERMANICO DACICO PONTIFICI MAXIMO TRIBUNICIA POTESTATE XVII CONSULI VI PATRI PATRIAE AD DECLARANDUM QUANTAE ALTITUDINIS MONS ET LOCUS SIT EGESTUS.

S(enatus) P(opulus)q(ue) R(omanus) | Imp(eratori) Caesari divi Nervae f(ilio) Nervae | Traiano Aug(usto) Germanic(o) Dacico | pont(ifici) max(imo) trib(unicia) pot(estate) XVII co(n)s(uli) VI p(atri) p(atriae) | ad declarandu(m) quantae altitu | dinis mons et locus sit egestus.
NOTE: On this print, the inscription differs in several respects from the original. In addition to not observing the original line breaks, in this print the first line of the inscription on the base of the column is abbreviated to “SPQR”, though on the actual monument it is written “Senatus Populusque Romanus.” In addition, “Germanic(o)” should be abbreviated to “Germ(anico)”; “pont(ifici) max(imo)” should be “pontif(ici) maximo”. The print is missing “Imp(eratori) VI” after “trib(unicia) pot(estate) XVII” in the fourth line, and in the final line it is missing “tant[is oper]ibus” after “locus.” Compare with Source Text below.

Senatus popolusque Romanus
Imp(eratori) Caesari dìvì Nervae f(ilio) Nervae
Traiano Aug(usto) Germ(anico) Dacico, pontif(ici)
maximo, trib(unicia) pot(estate) X̅V̅I̅I̅, imp(eratori) V̅I̅, co(n)s(uli) V̅I̅, p(atri) p(atriae),
ad declarandum, quantae altitudinis
mons et locus tant[is oper]ibus sit egestus.
{CIL VI.960 cf. VI p. 3070 et VI p. 3777 et VI p. 4310}

The Senate and People of Rome (dedicate this column) to the Emperor Caesar Nerva Trajan Augustus, son of the divine Nerva, Germanicus, Dacicus, pontifex maximus, invested with the tribunican power for the 17th time, proclaimed emperor six times, consul for the 6th time, father of the fatherland, as an illustration of the height of the hill that was demolished in the course of these great labors.
Claudii Duchetti formis. Ambrosius Brambilla fecit.
At the press of Claudio Duchetti. Ambrosio Brambilla made it.

inscription.text: Circi Maximi acuratissima descriptio diligentissime delineata per Pyrrum Ligorium pictorem Neapolitanum ex veterum et classicorum auctorum monumentis ad unguem repraesentata et summa cum Claudii Ducheti cura et impensa ex aeneis tabulis mirifice incisis formata Rome Anno Domini MDLXXXI.

Circi Maximi acuratissima descriptio diligentissime delineata per Pyrrum Ligorium pictorem Neapolitanum ex veterum et classicorum auctorum monumentis ad unguem repraesentata et summa cum Claudii Ducheti cura et impensa ex aeneis tabulis mirifice incisis formata Rome Anno Domini MDLXXXI.

Most accurate drawing of the Circus Maximus, delineated most diligently by the Neapolitan painter Pirro Ligorio from the monuments of the ancient and superior progenitors; depicted precisely with the greatest care and expense by Claudio Duchetti, composed marvelously in incised bronze plates. Rome, the year of the Lord 1581.
Circus longitudine stadiis tribus patebat, latitudine vero stadio uno sed cum aedeficiis iugerum quarternum.
Circus longitudine stadiis tribus patebat, latitudine vero stadio uno sed cum aedeficiis iugerum quarternum.
The Circus extended three stades in length and one true stade in width, but with the built structures it measured four acres.

descriptionSet.description: Although the text at the bottom of the print identifies this structure as the "sepulchre" of Septimius Severus, this was not its original function. Most likely, it was a monumental facade to the Palatine Hill in the architectural mold of a scenae frons. It has been proposed also that is may have bean a monumental nymphaeum, or fountain, but no traces of waterworks remain in the area so this was probably not the case. For further information, see Richardson, pg. 350, s.v. Septizodium. The Septizodium was destroyed in the 16th century by Pope Sixtus V in order to repurpose the marble. Knowledge of the inscription comes from its having been recorded in epigraphic sylloges and prints such as this one.

Romae MDXLVI

Luci Septimii Severi Caesaris in via appia quantum quidam consequi coniectura poterunt Sepulchrum Septizonii titulo temporum iniuria paene distructum ceteris partibus vel corruptis vel conlabsis negligentia superioris aevi moti quod superest memoriam veterum propagantes effinximus. Romae MDXLVI

Luci Septimii Severi Caesaris in Via Appia quantum quidam consequi coniectura poterunt sepulchrum Septizonii titulo temporum iniuria paene distructum ceteris partib(us) vel corruptis vel conlabsis negligentia superioris aevi moti quod superest memoriam veterum propagantes effinximus. Romae MDXLVI

As much as anyone is able to decipher through conjecture the form of the sepulcher of Lucius Septimius Severus Caesar on the Via Appia, called the Septizonium, nearly destroyed by the injuries of time with the remaining parts either in poor condition or falling down as a result of the neglect of the preceding generations, we, moved, have portrayed what remains, preserving for posterity the memory of things ancient. Rome, 1546.

The Emperor Caesar, son of the Divine Marcus Antoninus Pius Germanicus Sarmaticus [Marcus Aurelius], brother of the Divine Commodus, grandson of the Divine Nerva, great-grandson of the Divine Hadrian, great-great-grandson of the Divine Trajan, great-great-great-grandson of the Divine Nerva, Lucius Septimius Severus Pius Pertinax Augustus Arabicus Adiabenicus Parthicus maximus, Pontifex Maximus, invested with the tribunician power for the eleventh time, proclaimed emperor eleven times, having been consul three times, Father of the Fatherland and Emperor Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Pius Felix Augustus, invested with the tribunician power for the sixth time, consul, most fortunate and most noble prince...

description.source: Hilary Barker

descriptionSet.description: Although the text at the bottom of the print identifies this structure as the "sepulchre" of Septimius Severus, this was not its original function. Most likely, it was a monumental facade to the Palatine Hill in the architectural mold of a scenae frons. It has been proposed also that is may have bean a monumental nymphaeum, or fountain, but no traces of waterworks remain in the area so this was probably not the case. For further information, see Richardson, pg. 350, s.v. Septizodium. The Septizodium was destroyed in the 16th century by Pope Sixtus V in order to repurpose the marble. Knowledge of the inscription comes from its having been recorded in epigraphic sylloges and prints such as this one.

Valerius Bradua Mauricus pontif. et Antonia Vitellia amici Q. Fabius Honoratus T. Annaeus Placidus

To the Spirits of the Dead. The tomb of Marcus Antonius Antius Lupus, praetor, patrician, augur, quaestor, member of the Sodales Titii, military tribune of the 2nd auxiliary legion, pius, faithful, member of the board of ten for judging lawsuits, prefect of the Latin holidays, overthrown by force, whose memory was restored by resolution of the Senate, his friends Marcus Valerius Bradua Mauricus, a priest, Antonia Vitellia, Quintus Fabius Honoratus, and Titus Annaeus Placidus brought to completion having been the undertaking at that time [of his death] of Claudia Regilla his wife and Antia Marcellina his daughter to attest their piety towards him and to praise his name in perpetuity.

Ancient large, square-set, marble tomb on the Via Ostiensis near the third milestone from the city, famous for its other ornaments of fasces and axes.

To the spirits of the dead. To Publius Vibius Marianus, son of Publius, Proconsul and Twice chief centurion of his post in the province of Sardinia, Tribune of the 10th Praetorian cohort, Prefect of the 4th urban Night Watch, Chief Centurion of the 2nd Italian Legion, captain of the Frumentarii of the 3rd Gallic Legion, springing from Julia Dertona in Italy, the sweetest father, and to Regina, the greatest and dearest mother, Vibia Maria Maxima, daughter and heir, provided (this monument).

Representation of the ancient porphyrite grave near the second milestone from the city on the Via Nomentana, the sepulcher of Constantia, daughter of Constantine the Great—engraved with the same forms in front, reverse, left and right; regarded popularly with a variable reputation on account of the hardness of the marble or the carelessness of the artist, or the barbarity of the present age.

To Marcus Pompeius Asper, son of Marcus, of the Aniensian voting-tribe, centurion of the Fifteenth Legion Apollinaris, centurion of the Third Praetorian Cohort, primuspilus (prefect) of the Third Legion Cyrenaica, praefectus castrorum (camp prefect) of the Twentieth Legion Victrix, Atimetus, freedman, keeper of the sacred chickens, made this; and to himself and to Marcus Pompeius Asper, son of Marcus, of the Collina voting-tribe, his son and to Marcus Pompeius Asper, son of Marcus, of the Collina boting-tribe, his younger son and to Cincia Saturnina his wife.

IN AEDIB. FEDERICI CARD. DE CAESIS SUB VATICANO TABULA MARM. COHORTIUM SIGNIS DUOBUS AQUILAQ. LEGIONARIA ATQUE ALIIS CUM INSTRUMENTIS BELLICIS TUM CAVEA PULLARIA INSCRIPTIONIBUSQ. PERELEGANTIBUS INSIGNIS.

Marble tablet showing the battle-standards of two cohorts and the legionary eagle with other instruments of war as well as a chicken pen with elegant emblems and inscriptions, in the home of Cardinal Federico de Caesis behind the Vatican.

inscription.text: Lector iucundissime, ac veterum rerum studiosiss. finescis, instrumentorum, quae in hac tabella graphice excusa videntur, rationem, his pauculis verbis facillime te intellecturum spero. Nan ex his characteribus, quae infra notati sunt, nullo omnia labore percipies. Igitur que A litera adscripta hic subnotantur Simpulum, sive Simpinium aut Simpivium est, quo e Cratere aquam Sacrificulus hauriebat. B. vero Sacerdotis pileum tibi demonstrat C. Lituum D. Aspergillum E. Securim, qua Hostia mactatur a Popa F. Secespita, qua exta Sacrificiorum ministri partiebantur. G. arcula laureata est: ubi Ihus asservabatur H. Candelabrum. I. pateram indicat. K. Urceolum curamo Laureo qui pacis symbolum est. L. ubi pugio sit, indicat, quo hostia ingulabatur. M. demu velu quo Pont. Maximus caput inter sacrificandum contegebat ex veteri Romanae religionis instituto: Quae omnia hodie in Capitolio intra Conservatorum Palatium visuntur.

Most agreeable reader, most studious of ancient things, you begin easily I hope to make out an account of instruments with these few words, which are seen printed in this exquisite picture. By these markings, which are noted below, you will perceive all things with no labor. Accordingly, the ladle by which the sacrificing priest drank the water from the bowl is subscribed by the inserted letter A. B refers for you however to the cap of the priest. C. Curved staff D. Holy water sprinkler E. Ax by which the priest sacrifices the victim F. Knife by which the entrails of the sacrifices are divided up by the attendants G. Casket adorned with laurel H. Candelabra I. indicates saucer K. Pitcher with laurel, which is the symbol of peace L. indicates where the knife by which the victim is dispatched lies M. the shroud by which the head priest covers up the head to be sacrificed according to the ancient custom of Roman religion: which can be seen in all respects today in the Capitol
Romae Claudii Duchetti formis

inscription.text: Solitauriliorum sacrificiorum; quae, lustro peracto, Verris Arietis ac Tauri (quod integri solidique corporis sint) immolatione, Censores Urbem lustrantes, omnibus Centuriis et Equitibus in campum Martium convocatis, sollemni more faciebant; ex antiqua marmorea tabella, Romae, parieti cuidam, in Marci, fixa; illustris effigies. Ant. Lafrerii

of sacrifices, which the Censors, expiating the city, carried out in solemn fashion, the purification having been completed, the boar, ram, and bull immolated (because they are vigorous and solid of body), all Centuries and Knights having been called to the Field of Mars; from an ancient image fixed on a house wall in Rome; an illustrious likeness; Antonio Lafreri

inscription.text: OPUS PRAXITELIS.
Opus Praxitelis
Opus Praxitelis

Opus Praxitelis.
{CIL VI 10038 cf. VI 33821}
Work of Praxiteles
OPUS FIDIAE
Opus fidiae
Opus Fidiae

Opus Fidiae.
{CIL VI 10038 cf. VI 33821}
Work of Phidias

HEUS TU QUI PRAETERIS MORARE PAULUM AC INSPICE IN QUIRINALI HI SUNT EQUI MARMOREI MUTILI ATQUE GRANDES ARTE VICTA NATURA PARENS SPIRITUM CUR EPIRIT QUID PRAXITELES ET FIDIAS EFFINXERE ISTOS AEMULAMUR SAT DIXI ABEL VALE SALVE MISCE BIBE DA MI...

Heus tu qui praeteris morare paulum ac inspice in Quirinali hi sunt equi marmorei mutili atque grandes arte victa natura parens spiritum cur eripit quid Praxiteles et Fidias effinxere istos aemulamur sat dixi abel vale salve misce bibe da mi.

Hey you who pass by, stop a while and look. Here on the Quirinal are the great, broken marble horses, nature appearing conquered by art, wherefore that which Praxiteles and Phidias fashioned snatches away the breath. I endeavor to equal them satisfactorily. I have said (?). Hail, be well, farewell, mingle, drink, do this for me.
ANT. LAFRERI
Antonii Lafreri
Ant(onii) Lafreri
[At the press of] Antonio Lafreri

inscription.text: ΓΛYKWN AΘHNAIOC EΠOIEI

ΓΛYKWN AΘHNAIOC EΠOIEI
{Inscriptiones Graecae Urbis Romae IV, 1556}
Glykon of Athens made me
Iacobus Bossius Belga. incidit
Iacobus Bossius Belgarum incidit.
Iacobus Bossius Belga(rum) incidit.
Jacob Bos of Belgium engraved it.

Omnium elegantissimum Herculis signum Gliconis Atheniensis peritissimi artificis manu fabre factu[m]. Quod Paulo III Pont. max. in thermarum Antoninianar[um] ruderibus inuentum et in domus Farnesianae ad campum Florae interiori porticu[m] locatum. Ant. Lafrerius Sequanus aeneis formis diligenter expressit Anno MDLXII.

Omnium elegantissimum Herculis signum Gliconis Atheniensis peritissimi artificis manu fabre factum. Quod Paulo III Pontifice Maximo in thermarum Antoninianarum ruderibus inuentum et in domus Farnesianae ad campum Florae interiori porticum locatum. Antonius Lafrerius Sequanus aeneis formis diligenter expressit Anno MDLXII.

Omnium elegantissimum Herculis signum Gliconis Atheniensis peritissimi artificis manu fabre factu(m). Quod Paulo III Pont(ifice) Max(im)o in thermarum Antoninianar(um) ruderibus inuentum et in domus Farnesianae ad campum Florae interiori porticu(m) locatum. Ant(onius) Lafrerius Sequanus aeneis formis diligenter expressit Anno MDLXII.

Statue of Hercules, most elegant of all, produced skillfully by the hand of the most experienced artist, Glykon of Athens; which was found during the pontificate of Paul III in pieces in the Antonine Baths and was placed in the Farnese Palace near the Campo dei Fiori in an inner colonnade. Antonio Lafreri carefully copied it with bronze molds, 1562

inscription.text: Commodi Imp. faciem atque habitum Herculis induti ac pusionem infantem (cuius errore periit) brachio laevo gestantis statua insignis ita ut in Belvedere (pont horto sic vulgo appellato) extat.
Commodi Imperatoris faciem atque habitum Herculis induti ac pusionem infantem (cuius errore periit) brachio laevo gestantis statua insignis ita ut in Belvedere (pont horto sic vulgo appellato) extat.

Commodi Imp(eratoris) faciem atque habitum Herculis induti ac pusionem infantem (cuius errore periit) brachio laevo gestantis statua insignis ita ut in Belvedere (pont horto sic vulgo appellato) extat.

Famous statue of the Emperor Commodus wearing the appearance and dress of Herculis and carrying an infant youth (which has been lost by error) on his left forearm that stands in the Belvedere (popularly called the pleasure garden)

inscription.text: AMICE QUAM TU HIC EFFIGIEM SPECTATU RARAM DEMIRARIS OCEANI EST. ANNIS SUPERIORIB. ROMAE REPERTA AD ARCUM CAMPILIANI UBI ANTEA NILI ET TIBERIS QUOR. NUNC IN VATICANO INTRA PONTIFICUM HORTIS VISUNTUR IMAGINES SED HUIUSCE SPECTATU DIGNUM SIMULACHRUM NUNC IN AEDIBUS IO BAPTISTAE ET IO VINCENTII FABIORUM ROMAE AD SARRAE AREAM VISITUR INTERIM QUOD HUNC IN MODUM TIBI REPRHESENTATUR OCEANUS: NICOLAO BEATRICIO LOTHARINGO GRATIAS HABE VALE ROMAE. DLX

Friend, you marvel at seeing here the rare image of the ocean, which was discovered in Rome in the latest years in Rome near the Arch of Campilianus. Today images are seen within the Vatican grounds, but his worthy likeness is now looked at in the households of the Baptist and of the Vincentius in the meantime for Ocean is displayed for you in this way: Have thanks for Nicolas Beatrizet and be well in Rome.
Romae Claudii Duchetti formis

inscription.text: Hac vetusta marmorea tabula, quae Romae in aedibus Octaviani Zeno prope theatrum Pompeii I campum Florae extat, hisce signis ornata, veteres, veteres rerum naturalium periti optimi agricolae munus significare volerunt. Qui assiduo labore, die noctuque, tribus solis, quattuor lunae stationibus, et naturali utrusque sideris cursu observatis, fortitudine, providentia, fide, et diligentia, terram fatigando rem agranam tractat et proinde carum frugum quae lucis I tenebrarum tempore creantur, oriuntur, excolunturque uberrimum pioventum fert.

By this ancient marble picture, decorated with these images, which exists in the house of Octavian Zeno in the Floran field near the theatre of Pompeii the Great, ancient farmers, the most skilled and noblest, wished to show the gifts of natural things. He who manages the farmed property by overcoming the land, through constant labor, night and day, through the three watches of the sun and four of the moon, through fortitude, providence, faith, and diligence and hence he bears the most fertile and beloved of the fruits which are created, cultivated, and born at once into the light from the darkness.
Antonii Lafrerii Sequani formeis Anno. DLXIII

inscription.text: Pyrrhi Molossorum regis Imperatorum sui temporis fortissimi et rei militaris peritissimi ducis Simulachrum, quod Romae in porticu domus Maximi Archiepiscopi Amalphitanorum situm Ant. Salamanca aeneis typis suis delineavit et publicae studiosrum utilitati Anno DLXII. in lucem misit.

Statue of King Pyrrhus of Empire of Epirus, strongest of his time and most skilled leader in military matters, which is situated in Rome in the portico of the palace of the archbishop. Antonio Salamanca delineated this from his bronze casts and put it into the light for the public benefit of the studious.
Iacobus Bossius Belga incidit

inscription.text: [Quest' e di Rom]a un nobil cittadino/ ... /[Come v]edete, et ha nome Marfuori

PACI AUGUST. SACRUM L. CAESILIUS TAURISIUS TARQUINES C. PORTUMIUS PHOEBUS II, L. SILIUS CARFUS, L. STATIUS PATROCLUS II, D. NOVIUS PRISCUS, P. SUILLIUS CELER, TI. CLAUDIUS HERMETIS, L. HELIUS, P. AGRASIUS P. F. MARCELIUS, CURATORES TRIB. SUC. IUNIOR. S.P.D.D. PERMISSU. M. ARRICINI CLEMENTIS

Sacrifice to the Augustan peace. Lucius Caesilius Taurisius Tarquin, Gaius Portumius Phoebus, a duumvir, Lucius Silius Carfus, Lucius Statius Patroclus, a duumvir, Decius Novius Priscus, Publius Suillius Celer, Tiberius Claudius Hermetis, Lucius Helius, Publius Agrasius Marcelius, son of Publius, curators, junior tribunes, by decree of the town council and with the permission of Marcus Arricinus Clemens, with their own money

VICTORIAE IMP CAESARIS VESPASIANI AUGUSTI SACRUM TRIB. SUC. CORP. IULIANI C. IULIUS HERMES MENSOR BIS HON INCURAT FUNCTUS ET NOMINE C. IULI REGLILLI FILI DE SUO FECIT CUI POPULUS EIUS CORPORIS INMUNITATEM SEX. CENTURIARUM DECREVIT

Sacrifice to the victory of Emperor Caesar Vespasian Augustus, Gaius Julius Hermes Mensor, tribune of the Julian guild, having discharged his duty, procured honors twice and, in the name of his son Gaius Julius Regillus, made this with his own money, and for whom the people of his guild decreed tax immunity from the sixth voting unit
RESTITUTORI URBIS ROM...ET EXTINCTORI FESTIFE...D.N. FL. IUL. CONSTANTIO VIC...SEMPER AUGU...NERATIUS CEREALIS V.C...VICESACRA IUDICANS...
To the rebuilder of the Roman city...and destroyer...our emperor, Flavius Julius Constantine...always...the most distinguished Neratius Cerealis...judging...

inscription.text: Quest' e di Roma un nobil cittadino Il qual(ne alcun si pensi ch'io lo inganni) Naqque con questa barba e' in questi panni E fu si grande in sin ch'era piccino Non mangio mai ne bevue et e' vicino A forse piu di Mille Dugento anni Et non di meno i disagi et li affanni Tutti del mondo non stima un quattrino Semper et si puo dir nudo, al aqua, al Sole, Aluento, e' in terra Stassi senza tetto Ne un dente pur; non ch'altro mai li duole, Di natura quieto, grave', ischietto Candido; di pochissime parole', Et a molte faccende atto e' perfetto Anchor che per dispetto Gia lo storpiassin certi traditori Come vedete, et ha nome Marfuori. Romae Claudii duchetis formis. 1581.

inscription.text: Io non son (come paio) un Babbuino stroppiato, senza piedi, et senza mani, Nemen con glialtri membri sconci et strani, La simmia son di Niccolo Zoppino. Ma son quel famosissimo Pasquino che tremar faccio i Signor piu Soprani, stupir forastieri et Paesani Quando compango in volgare, o in latino La mia persona e' fatta in tal maniera Per i colpi, e, hor questo hor quel in accocca Per ch'io dico i lor falli a buona cera. Ma infin ch'io ha l'usata lingua in bocca Non ne fo stima, anchor che'l resto pera sempre cantaro, Zara a chi tocca Che se la gente sciocca Non si vuol rimaner de i falli suoi Chi terra me' che no'1 ridica poi
ANT. LAFRERI FORMIS ROMAE DL
Pasquin tu fuste e' sardi semper un pazo Tisai in ogni forma traffor mate' se ti voi alli donne grato fare Per che non ti tra'fformi int' Vn Ca
Non dir mai ver se voi Viuer in Corte'
Ve Com iosto per Cantar troppo il Vero
Romae caput Attamen ipsa
Nevertheless, the very head of Rome
filia summi Roma Vale
Be well Rome, daughter of the greatest
Pazzia sapientia
Aeternum qui se aut Bullam esse sequi ex
Ecce quam bonum et quam iocundum habitare fratres in Unum
Behold brothers, how good and how pleasing to live in one
Lurcones scurra nebu lones Vobis ego
Che fate gni a torno babioni Non conoscete la vera effigie mia Io son pasquin col malcge dio vi dia vi possa venir i Strangoglioni

Hae statuae, in antiquissimo mamore, erudita manu sculptae, maiestate, vetustatisque veneratione conspicuae, ac celebres; Romae, in hortis Faederici Cardinalis, Caesii, omnis generis signorum plenis; una, ampliore loco, honoris caussa, collocatae

Hae statuae, in antiquissimo mamore, erudita manu sculptae, maiestate, vetustatisque veneratione conspicuae, ac celebres; Romae, in hortis Faederici Cardinalis, Caesii, omnis generis signorum plenis; una, ampliore loco, honoris caussa, collocatae

These statues, in the most ancient marble, scupted by a skilled hand, are known for their grandeur, veneration of time; in the gardens of the Cardinal Faedericus, of the Caesii; placed in a most notible location, for the sake of honor
ANT. LAFRERI DXLVIIII

inscription.text: Castello S. Angelo di Roma
Castello Sant Angelo di Roma
Castello S[ant] Angelo di Roma
Castel Sant'Angelo of Rome

En tibi quisquis es lector iucundissime quem Aeneis Nicolai Beatricii Lotharingi pereleganter formis repraesentata romanor. caesarum aedificia delectant Imp. Caesaris Hadriani Aug. effigiatum haud inepte mausoleum quod et Bonifacius Nonus e Tomacella Familia Pont. Maximus primus omnium in castri formam communiit idq. etiam post illum Alexander Borgius Sextus huius nominis Pont. Max. Caroli Viii Gallorum Regis consilio in hanc quam vides admirande munitionis formam redegit. Vale.

En tibi quisquis es lector iucundissime quem aeneis Nicolai Beatricii Lotharingi pereleganter formis repraesentata romanorum caesarum aedificia delectant Imperatoris Caesaris Hadriani Augusti effigiatum haud inepte mausoleum quod et Bonifacius Nonus e Tomacella Familia Pontifex Maximus primus omnium in castri formam communiit idque etiam post illum Alexander Borgius Sextus huius nominis Pontifex Maximus Caroli Viii Gallorum Regis consilio in hanc quam vides admirande munitionis formam redegit. Vale.

En tibi quisquis es lector iucundissime quem aeneis Nicolai Beatricii Lotharingi pereleganter formis repraesentata romanor[um] caesarum aedificia delectant Imp[eratoris] Caesaris Hadriani Aug[usti] effigiatum haud inepte mausoleum quod et Bonifacius Nonus e Tomacella familia Pont[ifex] Maximus primus omnium in castri formam communiit idq[ue] etiam post illum Alexander Borgius Sextus huius nominis Pont[ifex] Max[imus] Caroli Viii Gallorum Regis consilio in hanc quam vides admirande munitionis formam redegit. Vale.

Behold, whoever you are most agreeable reader, whom the structures of the Roman Caesars, represented elegantly in the images in bronze of Nicolas Beatrizet, and the mausoleum of the emperor Caesar Hadrian, portrayed not at all ineptly, delight. Pope Boniface IX of the Tomacelli family, first of all men, fortified on all sides the form of the castle and after him, Pope Alexander VI Borghese, on the advice of Charles VIII King of the French, admirably reduced the form of the fortifications to that which you see. Farewell.

inscription.text: CASTELLO S. ANGELO DI ROMA
CASTELLO S. ANGELO DI ROMA
Castle Saint Angelo of Rome

EN TIBI QUISQUIS ES LECTOR IUCUNDISSIME QUEM AENEIS NICOLAI BEATRICII LOTHARINGI PERELEGANTER FORMIS REPRAESENTATA ROMANOR. CAESARUM AEDIFICIA DELECTANT IMP. CAESARIS HADRIANI AUG. EFFIGIATUM HAUD INEPTE MAUSOLEUM QUOD ET BONIFACIUS NONUS E TOMACELLA FAMILIA PONT. MAXIMUS PRIMUS OMNIUM IN CASTRI FORMAM COMMUNIIT IDQ. ETIAM POST ILLUM ALEXANDER BORGIUS SEXTUS HUIUS NOMINIS PONT. MAX. CAROLI VIII GALLORUM REGIS CONSILIO IN HANC QUAM VIDES ADMIRANDE MUNITIONIS FORMAM REDEGIT. VALE.

EN TIBI QUISQUIS ES LECTOR IUCUNDISSIME QUEM AENEIS NICOLAI BEATRICII LOTHARINGI PERELEGANTER FORMIS REPRAESENTATA ROMANORUM CAESARUM AEDIFICIA DELECTANT IMPERATORIS CAESARIS HADRIANI AUGUSTI EFFIGIATUM HAUD INEPTE MAUSOLEUM QUOD ET BONIFACIUS NONUS E TOMACELLA FAMILIA PONTIFEX MAXIMUS PRIMUS OMNIUM IN CASTRI FORMAM COMMUNIIT IDQUE ETIAM POST ILLUM ALEXANDER BORGIUS SEXTUS HUIUS NOMINIS PONTIFEX MAXIMUS CAROLI VIII GALLORUM REGIS CONSILIO IN HANC QUAM VIDES ADMIRANDAE MUNITIONIS FORMAM REDEGIT. VALE.

EN TIBI QUISQUIS ES LECTOR IUCUNDISSIME QUEM AENEIS NICOLAI BEATRICII LOTHARINGI PERELEGANTER FORMIS REPRAESENTATA ROMANOR[UM] CAESARUM AEDIFICIA DELECTANT IMP[ERATORIS] CAESARIS HADRIANI AUG[USTI] EFFIGIATUM HAUD INEPTE MAUSOLEUM QUOD ET BONIFACIUS NONUS E TOMACELLA FAMILIA PONT[IFEX] MAXIMUS PRIMUS OMNIUM IN CASTRI FORMAM COMMUNIIT IDQ[UE] ETIAM POST ILLUM ALEXANDER BORGIUS SEXTUS HUIUS NOMINIS PONT[IFEX] MAX[IMUS] CAROLI VIII GALLORUM REGIS CONSILIO IN HANC QUAM VIDES ADMIRANDAE MUNITIONIS FORMAM REDEGIT. VALE.

Behold, whoever you are most agreeable reader, whom the structures of the Roman Caesars, represented elegantly in the images in bronze of Nicolas Beatrizet, and the mausoleum of the emperor Caesar Hadrian, portrayed not at all foolishly, delight. Pope Boniface IX, first of all men, strengthened the form of the castle and after him, Alexander Borgese VI, on the advice of King Charles VIII of the French, reduced this form of the impressive fortifications, which you see
Apud Eredes Claudii Ducheti
Before the heirs of Claudio Duchetti

inscription.text: DISEGNO DELA BENEDITIONE DEL PONTEFICE NELA PIAZA DE SANTO PIETRO
Christicolae huc alacres concu(r)rite saepe fideles: Hic deus in terris numinis alta subit.
Always faithful Christians, assemble here eager: here God ascends a height in the earths of the divine
Sacris dum manibus populo benedicit amice Assistas: Petri nam gerit ipse vices
O friend, let yourself stand in the crowd while he blesses with sacred hands: for this very man bears the successions of Peter
Praesulis hic summi benedictio celsa notatur. Hac cruce signatos demonis ars refugit
Here, the lofty blessing of the greatest bishop is noted. Here the arts of the devil flee the signs by the cross
CLAUDII DUCHETTI FORMIS AMBROSIUS BRAM. FECIT
By the models of Claudio Duchetti Ambrogio Brambilla made it

inscription.text: La presente Figura dimostra una armadura o vero incavallatura delle volte di San Pietro Di Roma fatta da M Ant Da Sa'gallo T ancora messa inopera da Michael Ang Buonaroto pur nelle medsime volte fatte dalui e volendo sapere la sua misure disotto a detta ve la Canna Romana partito in parte 10 detti palmi

Sara utile a qual si voglia persona haver messo nella presente Carta le misure antich emoderne qual sono Jolte da quelle stesse di campido: glio seruono a architetti muratori e falegniani T ameranti et adaltri artieri ch esercitano le misure aparte: nenti alla loro perfessione.
Ant. Lafreri Sequani Formis Roma Anno. 1561

descriptionSet.description: Regarding the inscription on the base of the Columna Rostrata, only the letters inscribed in all majuscules were visible at the time of this engraving. Those in italics are an unknown scholar's reconstruction of the missing parts of the inscription. The italics are preserved in the transcription below for ease of reference. Note that this 16th century reconstruction of the inscription differs significantly from that proposed by modern scholarship. See the Source Text below for the currently accepted version.

inscription.text: C. Duilius Consul, primus Romanorum Poenis classe devictis de navali victoria triumphum egit. Ob eam rem ei in foro Rom. positam fuisse statuam ex SC una cum columna rostrata varii auctores prodidere. Eius columnam stylobatam superioribus annis ex Capitolinis ruderibus versus forum egestam: nunc autem in Capitolium translatam, in gratiam antiquitatis studiosorem ea qua restituta est forma cum inscriptione ipsa typis mandavimus.

Caius Duilius Consul, primus Romanorum Poenis classe devictis de navali victoria triumphum egit. Ob eam rem ei in foro Romano positam fuisse statuam ex Senatus Consultu una cum columna rostrata varii auctores prodidere. Eius columnam stylobatam superioribus annis ex Capitolinis ruderibus versus forum egestam: nunc autem in Capitolium translatam, in gratiam antiquitatis studiosorem ea qua restituta est forma cum inscriptione ipsa typis mandavimus.

C(aius) Duilius Consul, primus Romanorum Poenis classe devictis de navali victoria triumphum egit. Ob eam rem ei in foro Rom(ano) positam fuisse statuam ex S(enatus) C(onsultu) una cum columna rostrata varii auctores prodidere. Eius columnam stylobatam sup(er)ioribus annis ex Capitolinis ruderibus versus forum egestam: nunc autem in Capitolium translatam, in gratiam antiquitatis studiosorem ea qua restituta est forma cum inscriptione ipsa typis mandavim(us).

Gaius Duilius, consul, first among the Romans, led a triumph, having defeated the Carthaginians in naval victory. On the occasion of this affair, a column with beaked prows was placed in the Roman Forum by order of the Senate and various authorities brought forth a statue to him. His stylobate column in former years was removed from the rubble of the Capitoline hill facing the Forum. Now however it has been moved to the Capitol, by the favor of those who study ancient things, where its form was restored with its very own inscription of which we have provided an image.

Metae sudantis, praeterquamquod in numismatibus aliquot Vespasiani, Titi, et Domitiani Imp. percussa cernitur, vestigia apud amphitheatrum Titi extat, fons fuit sic dictus q[ui] ex eo manaret aqua[m] commoditati populi, ad ludos et spectacula quae in amphitheatro edebantur, accedentis.

Metae sudantis, praeterquamquod in numismatibus aliquot Vespasiani, Titi, et Domitiani Imperatores percussa cernitur, vestigia apud amphitheatrum Titi extat, fons fuit sic dictus qui ex eo manaret aquam commoditati populi, ad ludos et spectacula quae in amphitheatro edebantur, accedentis.

Metae sudantis, praeterquamquod in numismatibus aliquot Vespasiani, Titi, et Domitiani Imp(eratores) percussa cernitur, vestigia apud amphitheatrum Titi extat, fons fuit sic dictus q(ui) ex eo manaret aquam commoditati populi, ad ludos et spectacula quae in amphitheatro edebantur, accedentis.

A trace of the sweating column is distinguished stamped on some coins of the emperors Vespasian, Titus, and Domitian and exists before the Amphitheatre of Titus. The fountain was said to spring here, for the advantage of the people, and spectacles in addition to games were enjoyed in the amphitheatre.

Essendo scacciato da Roma Tarquinio Superbo, gli Romani tenendo che fosse cosa abbomineuole mangiar' il suo formento che all'hora haveva parte tagliato et parte era da tagliarse nel campo tiberino, lo gettorno nel Tevere con la paglia che per la staggione calda et il fiume basso insieme con altre brutture fece massa et diuiene isola, la quale puoi con industria et arte fu formata in forma di naue, et fu chiamata insola de Gioue licaonio, del suo tempo che ui fu edificato, gli furno anchora doi tempii uno de Esculapio, l’altro de fauno, con molti stupendi edeficii. Era di longhezza de un quarto de miglio et larghezza de cinquanta passi.

inscription.text: MAIESTATIS PONTIFICIAE DUM IN CAPELLA XISTI SACRA PERAGUNTUR ACCURATA DELINEATIO
MAIESTATIS PONTIFICIAE DUM IN CAPELLA XISTI SACRA PERAGUNTUR ACCURATA DELINEATIO
This accurate sketch of Papal grandeur while a mass is celebrated in the Sixtine Chapel

Smo D. N. celebrante missa o[mn]es Card[ina]les et Ep[iscop]i sunt parati pluvialibus et mitris. Quando celebratur p[onti]f[ic]e S. D. N. Papa Card[ina]les cappas habent rubeas vel violaceas iuxta temporis consuetudinem et Ep[iscop]i et Praelati h[ab]ent cappas violaceas. Familia S. D. N. semper rubeo vestitur.

Sanctissimo Domino Nostro celebrante missa omnes Cardinales et Episcopi sunt parati pluvialibus et mitris. Quando celebratur pontifice Sanctissimo Domino Nostri Papa Cardinales cappas habent rubeas vel violaceas iuxta temporis consuetudinem et Episcopi et Praelati habent cappas violaceas. Familia Sanctissimi Domini Nostri semper rubeo vestitur.

S[anctissi]mo D[omino] N[ostro] celebrante missa o[mn]es Card[ina]les et Ep[iscop]i sunt parati pluvialibus et mitris. Quando celebratur p[onti]f[ic]e S[anctissimo] D[omino] N[ostro] Papa Card[ina]les cappas habent rubeas vel violaceas iuxta temporis consuetudinem et Ep[iscop]i et Praelati h[ab]ent cappas violaceas. descriptionSet.description: The original plate contains 237 portraits terminating with the pontificate of Sixtus V (1585-1590). Two new sets of portraits were added at a later date. The first, including portraits of Urban VIII and Gregory XIV, was published at Rome by the heirs of Claudio Duchetti, ca. 1590-1591 (Cf. Hu 135b); the second, including the portraits of Innocent IX and Clement VIII, was published between 1592 and 1605 (Cf. Hu 135c and d).

inscription.text: CASTELLO S. ANGELO CON LA GIRANDOLA
CASTELLO S. ANGELO CON LA GIRANDOLA

Segno d’allegrezza qual’ si fa in Roma nel’ castel’ di S. Angelo vulgarmente chiamato la GIRANDOLA, como legendo intenderete, dovete saper’ che ogni anno in quel giorno che si fa la creatione et la coronatione del’ Pontifice a una hora di notte in circa, per tutte le finestre, campanili et loze dela cita si accende una gran’ quantita de lumi et per tutti li palazzi deli R[everendissi]mi Card[ina]li et Signori principali et getil’homini, nelle strade e piazze di essi si abrusciano molte botte con legne dentro di modo che facendo una gran’ fiamma pare che tutta la città vadi a fuoco. Dopoi quasi nel medesimo tempo dato un segno dal’ Palazzo Pappale al castello subito comincia la girandola in questo modo. Primamente si tira intorne le mura del castello una gran’ quantita de mortaletti con belliss[im]o ordine, doppoi questi molti colpi de artegliarie di modo che per un gran’ pezzo di tempo pare che tremi tutte la citta et cessato alquanto il fummo dela polvere, si accende il fuoco neli arbori deli torcioni del castello quali nela sumita hano accomodato una gran’ quantita de soffioni over’ ragie, quale volando accesa per aria pare che vadino al cielo, et callando al basso fano un schioppo nel’aere con certe stelle che pare sia aperto il cielo. Doppoi finito questo se ne accende nel maschio grande una tanta gran’ quantita che pare che tutto l’aere del mondo ne sia pieno, et pare che tutte le stelle del cielo cadeno a terra, cosa veramente stupendissima et molto marevigliosa da vedere; fassi anchora la medema girandola in giorni di feste principali et solemne, et anchora per qualche bona nova in segno d’allegrezza. Et per esser’ questa cosa degna da esser’ veduta et intesa da tutti, si é datto in luce novamente questo dissegno di essa con ogni diligenza.
